page.title: 16Coast - The Caves
page.content: The Wemyss caves have been used by many people over thousands of years and for a variety of purposes: from cave dwellers, the Picts, early Christians, Norsemen and smugglers, to the present day. Unfortunately the caves, which could be a major tourist attraction, now suffer from misuse, wilful damage and neglect. The caves are well known in archaeological circles for their prehistoric carvings. It has been said that there are more markings in them than all the other caves in Britain put together. The markings can be grouped under three headings: a) Pre- Christian (Pictish); b) Christian (Pictish); c) Viking. Sadly there are many markings which have been etched in modern days. These include initials, dates, and there is even a fish in Jonathan's Cave.
